sense.name: an endpoint in time
sense.examples: The summer afternoon drew to a close. At the close, the Dow Jones was up more than 50 points. Nixon's administration came to a close with his resignation. (historical endpoint)

sense.name: the conclusion of a communication
sense.examples: She signed her name and title at the close of the letter. The candidate's close was an upbeat summary of his past achievements in office. What should I say at the close of the introduction?

sense.name: the finale or ending of an opus or performance
sense.examples: The close of Mahler's 9th Symphony is a dying away of pianissimo notes. Only at the close of the novel does the protagonist find out who his father was. The critic described the show's close as a cacophony of caterwauling and high jinks set to an abysmal score.

sense.name: the act of shutting something, or drawing together
sense.examples: The door of the dungeon came to a close with a loud clang. In this dance step, the free foot comes to a close with the supporting foot on the third beat.

sense.name: an enclosure, or pen
sense.examples: The girl put the sheep into the close for the night. The farmer built a small close for the young horses.

sense.name: a narrow passage from a street to a courtyard
sense.examples: The child ran down the close after his ball. We turned off the street and followed a close into the courtyard of the small restaurant.

sense.name: the precinct of a cathedral
sense.examples: They belong to the close of St. Mary's. The priest has lived and worked in St. John's close for twenty years.
